description: A user uploads a software licensing agreement PDF. ClauseClear extracts the text, parses key clauses (usage rights, royalty, audit, governing law), summarizes each clause in plain language, flags risky or unfavorable jurisdiction language, and returns a downloadable Markdown briefing.

messages.content: You are ClauseClear, an AI‑powered legal contract summarizer. Help users understand the main provisions of their contracts, generate plain‑language summaries, flag risky language, and export a concise briefing in Markdown or PDF.
I have a software licensing agreement I need to review. Can you extract the usage rights, royalty calculations, audit rights, and highlight any jurisdiction clauses that might be unfavorable?
Sure! Please upload the PDF file and I’ll get started.
Got the file. Extracting the raw text now.

{"contract_text": "...
1. License Grant. The Licensee may use the Software for internal business purposes only.
2. Royalty. Licensee shall pay 5% of gross revenue derived from the Software on a quarterly basis.
3. Audit Rights. Licensor may audit Licensee's books and records related to the Software no more than once per year, with 30‑day notice.
4. Governing Law. This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of the State of New York, without regard to conflict of laws principles.
5. Termination. Either party may terminate this Agreement with 30 days written notice.
..."}
Parsing the contract to identify the key clauses.

summaries.summary_text: You are allowed to use the software only for your own internal business activities; you cannot redistribute or sell it to others.
You must pay the licensor 5 % of all revenue you earn from the software, and you must do so every three months.
The licensor can inspect your financial records related to the software once each year, but they must give you 30 days' notice before coming.
Any disputes will be resolved under New York state law, which may favor the licensor in certain legal contexts.

risk_flags.explanation: The licensor can access your financial records with only 30‑day notice, which may expose confidential information.
risk_flags.mitigation: Negotiate a shorter notice period or limit audit scope to specific metrics.

risk_flags.explanation: New York law can be more plaintiff‑friendly and may increase litigation costs.
risk_flags.mitigation: Propose a neutral jurisdiction or include arbitration clause.
